review.title: Bayesian Modeling of a Human MMORPG Player
review.abstract: This paper describes an application of Bayesian programming to the control of an autonomous avatar in a multiplayer role-playing game (the example is based on World of Warcraft). We model a particular task, which consists of choosing what to do and to select which target in a situation where allies and foes are present. We explain the model in Bayesian programming and show how we could learn the conditional probabilities from data gathered during human-played sessions.

sections.text: A very simple set of variables is as follows: We have the n characters as possible targets; each of them several bound variables. Health / Hangouts (HP) are discredited in 10 levels, from the lower to the higher. Distance (D) is discredited in 4 zones around the robot character: Contact, where it can attack with a contact weapon and then 3 distances, which are further out of range even for the longest distance weapon / spell. Ally (A) is a Boolean variable, which is allied with the robot character. Delta Hangouts (D) is a 3-rated interpolated value from the previous few seconds of combat, which inform about the injury (or nothing). Imminent death (ID) is also an interpolated value, which encodes HP and incoming attacks.

sections.heading: Perspectives
sections.text: These results are encouraging, but the most difficult aspect will be to complete the model for different types of tasks and to enable the robot to learn how to act by developing a predictive strategy, which must be applied in a real MMORPG, outside its simulation, in order to uncover all its shortcomings and to improve it. We foresee some difficulties in the future, for example, for many games there is a possibility that the skill variable will be very large and that it will cause too high a computing cost. Therefore, we propose to bundle the skills into Global Capabilities (GS), which is a general approach to break down the complexity of the computation and can be used with other variables.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: We believe that modeling human behavior has two major advantages: learning from examples played by humans, so that it can generate a behavior (control the character) and predict what the other players will do. Learning game sequences using a human model allows for rapid development of realistic AI in video games. It also reduces complexity by giving many possible actions and possible behaviors. Applying the model to other players for prediction allows the robot to have these predictions as input variables, and to act accordingly ("I think you think..."). Human players do long-term planning, consciously or not. However, modeling high-level cognition is very difficult. We assume that by modeling a reactive robot in terms of observable variables and predicted variables, we can emulate human planning.
